title: Understanding Joins in Databases
text: In database terminology, a "join" is an operation used to combine data from two different tables into a single table. Different types of joins determine how records from the tables are combined.

title: Types of Joins
text: There are several types of joins, such as "inner joins," "outer joins," "cross joins," and "self joins." Each type has its own rules about how records from the two tables are combined. This problem focuses on "cross joins."

title: Clarifying Cross Join
text: A "cross join" pairs every row in one table with every row in another table, resulting in a table that potentially has a very large number of records. This is different from other joins that usually match records based on certain criteria.
